subtitle: it's always very interesting
to me to speak about dreams in a fairly
short period of time
because i have been personally keeping a
dream journal
for almost 40 years now
i have been teaching other people about
dreams for about 35 years
and there are so many ways that they
have helped me
and changed my life as well as ways that
i've seen them change other people's
lives
it's a little bit of a challenge to
decide okay in 45 minutes what's going
to be the most
important thing to say about dreams so i
guess the first question i have is
how many of you remember your dreams i
would think most of you do because
you're here to program on dreams and
you know you kind of chuckle about that
but that in itself is a very
intriguing idea to me
is that dreaming is a universal
experience
it doesn't matter what age someone is
what
culture they're from what race they are
what religion they are
everybody dreams not everybody knows
that they dream
so if you ask people at your work
do you dream some people might say yes
some people might say no what i found is
when i start talking about dreams
oftentimes people who don't really pay
attention to dreams will say
i don't dream but there's this one dream
that i had
you know and i'll tell about some dream
from childhood they still remember
or they'll say i don't dream but now
that you think about it
and then they'll talk about some dream
that they actually do remember
so i think the truth is that
people who don't pay attention to dreams
don't really understand how valuable

throughout history there are people who
have paid attention to dreams
and some of those dreams have changed
the course of history this is something
i found out fairly recently
that mahatma gandhi who
was quite significant in freeing the
indian people from the british empire
one of the first big
events if you want to call it that where
he learned about
passive non-resistance or non-violence
was leading a tremendous number of
people down to the sea for what's called
the great salt march
what was happening is that the british
people were taxing the indian people for
salt
and he had a dream that gave him this
inspired vision that if he let all these
people down to the sea
and if they took the water out of the
sea and put it out in the sun
the sun would evaporate the water and
they'd be left with salt
so they could make their own salt they
didn't have to buy it from the british
and therefore they were able to avoid
paying the taxes
that was a dream inspired idea that he
paid attention to
harriet tubman who led a number of
slaves out of slavery through the
underground railway
the places that she discovered for the
underground railway came to her
in dreams both nighttime dreams and
waking visions
some people say she was a narcoleptic
meaning that she
slept often throughout the day
and i don't know if that's true but her
dreams
gave her the places that she was able to
use to free these slaves
dreams can be used for artistic
inspiration

i believe this story is accurate because

he dreamed that music and being a

and it was so haunting and so compelling
he didn't think it was his he figured it

were something kind of silly like

something love your legs
and he realized that that probably was

to produce the song yesterday so
that is one thing that's important to

they can give you inspired ideas that

sometimes you have to tweak it a little

there are inventions that came from

and one of my favorite stories about

so if you think about in the late 1800s

afro-americans had in this country it

didn't know what to do about it and one

some of those herbs were available in

she mixed up this potion and massaged it

she continued to use it and it continued

she gave it to some of her friends and

is quite a lot of money a lot more money

a woman who didn't even have the right
